quote: My infusion are supposed to be four hours but I think they always last at least six for whatever reason.
I’m grateful for the nurses; they always make me feel cared for during my infusions, even when I'm not having my best day.
Traveling hours just to sit in a chair for eight hours is taking a toll on my family and my work life.
I had so many issues with finding veins, and I'm a hard stick, as they say. Finally getting a port, so I hope things change.
Since switching to the new drug, I’ve actually started to feel stronger and more stable. I can't remember the last time I felt this good.
Even after increasing the dose, it doesn’t seem to be helping much—I feel like I’ve plateaued.
This medication saved my life, and I’m thankful every day it’s available to me.
After each dose, I get hit hard by nausea, headaches, and I’m always so fatigued the day after. It really messes with my schedule, even after my visits.
I feel like this is something many doctors treating Pompe don’t talk about, monitor, or try to prevent. The neurological impact gets overlooked and that’s really frightening for caregivers.

There’s promising news about a new treatment that can cross the blood-brain barrier to reduce glycogen production, rather than just clearing it from muscle. And if it works, patients may only need treatment every 12 weeks instead of every two!
These warriors are living longer than before, and now we’re seeing new symptoms. ERT can’t break the blood-brain barrier, which means the build-up in the brain can worsen over time.
Some days, the brain fog is so heavy I just want to check myself into a care facility. It’s hard on my family, and I don’t think they truly understand what I’m going through.
I’ve dealt with brain fog before, but after missing just one infusion, the difference was huge. More fatigue, more imbalance, and definitely more mental cloudiness, more everything.
We think the disease is damaging her brain now. Does anyone know if there are medications we can ask for to help treat this?

His doctors now believe Pompe is starting to impact his brain, including the brainstem. They suspect this neurological damage is behind his seizures and the fluctuations in his heart rate and body temperature.
I've read that reducing sugar and carbs might support brain health. Maybe diet really can act like medicine. Just some things this #pompestrong mom keeps thinking about...

His seizures have improved significantly. There haven’t been any major episodes in quite some time. His last heart check was great—no issues at all. Even his neurologist was impressed by his strength, with only slight weakness in his quads and hips.
